review: This novel follows Sera and Galina, two commoners and former members of a rebellion known as the Faithless. Their mother, a rebel leader, experimented on them, trapping dragon-like gods (Zmei) from another dimension within their bodies to empower them against the god-powered ruling elite led by the tyrannical Empress Isidora. The sisters must keep their Zmei a secret, as revealing them could endanger their own rebellion. Set against a Russian-inspired backdrop reminiscent of the Bolsheviks, the story weaves together themes of rebellion, political intrigue, and fantastical elements. The narrative flows quickly and maintains a well-balanced pace that keeps readers engaged. With a compelling mix of action, character development, and world-building, this tale offers a smooth and enjoyable reading experience.

The characters, especially Sera and Galina, are compelling as they navigate the intricate dynamics of the rebellion alongside their personal lives. The novel's inclusion of queer relationships and disability representation adds depth and fosters inclusivity. The on-page romances are tender, well-developed, and infused with just the right amount of spice, making them emotionally resonant.

The world-building is rich and immersive, featuring a unique magic system centered around the Zmei. The Russian-inspired fantasy setting is vividly crafted, reminiscent of *Shadow and Bone* and *Master and Margarita*, yet it offers a more accessible and less dense narrative.

This book is perfect for fans of Russian-inspired fantasy, especially those who loved *Shadow and Bone* or *Master and Margarita*. It delivers rich storytelling in a more accessible format, broadening its appeal to a wider audience.
conclusion: *To Cage a God* is a compelling and immersive fantasy novel with rich world-building, complex characters, and a unique magic system. The inclusion of queer relationships and disability representation adds depth and inclusivity, while the tender romances and fast-paced narrative make it an enjoyable read. I look forward to seeing the universe expand in the next installment.

review: I found the novel to be overly long and excessive. The writing style felt inflated, with sentences filled with unnecessary exposition.

As a fan of cover art, I often find myself drawn to intriguing audiobooks, and I typically enjoy the selections available on NetGalley, especially those from Bolinda, which consistently delivers high-quality productions. Unfortunately, this particular audiobook didn't meet my expectations.

The main issue I encountered was a sense of d√©j√† lu; I felt as though I had already read this story. The similarities to Katherine Arden‚Äôs Winternight trilogy were striking and hard to overlook. An author inevitably risks this when crafting a narrative so reminiscent of a beloved and successful work.
conclusion: While this book has elements that will appeal to Fantasy listeners, particularly with its planned sequel and long character arcs, I found it overlong, overblown, and lacking in originality. The audiobook performance, though earnest, was too emotionally charged for my taste. Despite these criticisms, I appreciate the opportunity to access this pre-release audiobook.

**Aspects:**
- **Cover Art and Initial Expectations:**  
  I‚Äôm a sucker for cover art, and that usually stands me in good stead. I generally devour all and every audiobook I can get approval for on NetGalley, and Bolinda produces some of the very best. However, this one just wasn‚Äôt all I thought it would be.

- **Appeal to Fantasy Listeners:**  
  I know ‚ÄòTo Cage a God‚Äô will appeal to other Fantasy listeners, especially because there‚Äôs a sequel planned. Readers can do the deep dive and know there‚Äôll be gratification with the long character arcs.

- **Pacing and Writing Style:**  
  Personally, I found the novel overlong and overblown. In terms of craft and style, Elizabeth May‚Äôs sentences felt puffed up with unnecessary telling.

- **Audiobook Performance:**  
  The narrator, Sofia Engstrand, is too earnest for my liking. She narrates every scene as if it were a climactic battle. The audiobook performance is too solemn and emotionally charged to my taste, even when scenes are low-key.

- **Originality and Similarity to Other Works:**  
  The biggest hitch for me is that I felt I‚Äôd already read this. It‚Äôs a case of d√©j√† lu, rather than d√©j√† vu. I could not get over the similarity to Katherine Arden‚Äôs Winternight trilogy. I suppose an author does run that risk if they choose to write something so similar to such a successful and well-loved earlier publication.

- **Gratitude for Access:**  
  Nonetheless, my thanks to Bolinda for generous access to another pre-release audiobook through NetGalley.

**Conclusion:**  
While ‚ÄòTo Cage a God‚Äô has elements that will appeal to Fantasy listeners, particularly with its planned sequel and long character arcs, I found it overlong, overblown, and lacking in originality. The audiobook performance, though earnest, was too emotionally charged for my taste. Despite these criticisms, I appreciate the opportunity to access this pre-release audiobook.

review: I was eager to read this book due to its captivating premise and storyline. The plot felt original and intriguing, particularly the concept of a God trapped in a body bestowing special powers.

I found it challenging to connect with most characters, except for Katya. Her pain, suffering, strength, and determination were portrayed compellingly, making her journey engaging. In contrast, the other characters came across as self-involved, which hindered my ability to root for them. The frequent use of multiple nicknames further complicated my connection to the cast. While the romantic elements were beautifully written and some chemistry was evident, the relationships often felt forced, preventing me from fully investing in them as I wished.
The worldbuilding and magic system were the standout features of the book‚Äîcaptivating and well-developed. However, I wished for a deeper connection, as I often found it challenging to stay engaged.
conclusion: While the book had an intriguing premise, strong worldbuilding, and a standout character in Katya, I struggled to connect with most of the characters and found the romances somewhat forced. The multiple nicknames for characters also detracted from my engagement. Overall, it was a mixed experience with some standout elements but room for improvement.

  I struggled to connect with most of the characters, except for Katya. Her pain, suffering, strength, and determination were portrayed well, and I enjoyed following her journey. However, the other characters felt self-involved, and I found it hard to root for them. Additionally, the use of multiple nicknames for each character made it harder to connect with them.  

- **Romance:**  
  The romances had beautifully written elements, and some of the chemistry was well-crafted. However, the relationships felt forced, and I struggled to root for them as much as I wanted to.  

- **Worldbuilding and Magic System:**  
  The worldbuilding and magic system were the best aspects of the book. I found them captivating and well-developed, though I wish I could have connected with them more deeply instead of struggling to stay engaged.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the book had an intriguing premise, strong worldbuilding, and a standout character in Katya, I struggled to connect with most of the characters and found the romances somewhat forced. The multiple nicknames for characters also detracted from my engagement. Overall, it was a mixed experience with some standout elements but room for improvement.  

**Rating Scores:**  
2.5/5

review: The plot suffers from a lack of action and progression. The first four chapters are bogged down by mundane activities, such as a character reflecting on the past, waking someone up, packing a suitcase, and a poorly executed magical bombing scene. Despite the potential for excitement, the execution is lackluster, leaving the story feeling stagnant and unengaging. The pacing is slow and drawn out, making the narrative feel unnecessarily stretched. In contrast to *All This Twisted Glory* by Tahereh Mafi, which remains entertaining despite its length, this story fails to capture the same interest.
The characters lack depth and vibrancy, resembling a damp newspaper. Their inability to evoke any emotional connection or interest significantly diminishes the overall reading experience.

The writing is criticized for its complexity and lack of clarity. Sentences are often convoluted, necessitating multiple rereads for comprehension. Additionally, the narrative's repetitive nature detracts from the experience, as it avoids engaging elements in favor of redundancy.
conclusion: The novel, inspired by Russian folklore, had the potential to be captivating but ultimately fell short due to its lack of action, uninteresting characters, poor writing, and slow pacing. The repetitive and overly complex narrative made it difficult for me to engage with the story, leading me to abandon it early on.

review: The novel follows sisters Galina and Sera, whose mother imprisoned gods within them using ancient secrets. Raised as weapons to topple a cruel empire, they seize control of the rebellion after their mother‚Äôs death. Sera reconnects with her estranged lover, the rebel leader, while Galina infiltrates the palace, where she meets an isolated princess who could either lead to her ruin or redemption. The central question is whether they can save the common folk. From the outset, the story captivates, with the author skillfully immersing readers in the rebellion's cause through vivid portrayals of the empress‚Äôs tyranny and the sisters‚Äô struggles.

Galina and Sera are captivating protagonists, deeply influenced by their mother‚Äôs legacy and their involvement in the rebellion. Sera‚Äôs lover, Vitaly, is a charming and loyal thief, enriching the romantic subplot. Meanwhile, the isolated princess in the palace adds an intriguing layer to Galina‚Äôs journey.

The idea of gods being trapped in human bones is both fascinating and captivating. However, I would have appreciated more background information about these gods to better understand their significance and history.
This gripping and intense read is not for the faint of heart. It delves into themes of power, rebellion, and sacrifice, highlighting the empress's cruelty and the struggles of the oppressed.
The relationship between Sera and Vitaly brings a delightful blend of sweetness and intrigue to the story, captivating readers who appreciate romantic subplots.
conclusion: This novel is a dark, captivating tale of rebellion, power, and sacrifice, with strong characters and an intriguing premise. While I wished for more depth regarding the gods, the story‚Äôs intensity and emotional stakes kept me thoroughly engaged.

review: The ending is satisfying, effectively resolving current storylines while paving the way for larger battles in future installments. This high-stakes book is filled with tension, intricate plots, rebellion, and a captivating magic system. The unique concept of gods as dragons imprisoned within a person's body adds depth to the narrative. With its relentless action, the story keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The characters in this story are delightfully morally ambiguous, often using foul language. Vitalik stands out as a morally black character who loves only one person, and I found his infuriating nature compelling‚Äîhis declarations are the highlight of the book. Sera, Galina, and Katya have endured significant trauma and abuse, and I was fully invested in their struggle against the truly evil empress. The narrative features two main romantic relationships, along with the dynamic between the two sisters and their co-conspirators. These relationships develop slowly but pay off beautifully.
I've always enjoyed this author's books, and although this one is quite different from their previous works, I still loved it.
conclusion: This book is a thrilling, action-packed read with morally complex characters, unique world-building, and satisfying slow-burn relationships. If you love stabby, foul-mouthed heroines, this book is for you!

review: I'm still uncertain about the purpose of caging the gods. As another reader pointed out, by the end, it felt like the gods served more as metaphors for the characters' emotions rather than a central plot element.

The main villain came across as cartoonish, with unclear motivations. The characters, regardless of whose perspective we followed, fluctuated between violent rebellion and thoughts about each other's romantic potential, which created a sense of confusion due to the lack of focus.

The story unfolds in a world inspired by the Russian Revolution, reminiscent of *Shadow and Bone*. However, it falls short of the intricate fantasy elements that made *Shadow and Bone* so captivating.

I was eager to read this book due to its intriguing premise, especially the concept of caging the gods. Unfortunately, this aspect was underdeveloped and fell short of my expectations. The story struggles with its identity‚Äîoscillating between a tense fantasy filled with life-or-death stakes and a romantasy that relies on convenient plot devices to ensure character survival. This inconsistency hindered my ability to fully engage with the narrative.
conclusion: While the premise of the book was intriguing and the narration was excellent, the story suffered from inconsistent tone, unclear character motivations, and a lack of focus on its central plot element‚Äîthe caging of the gods. Ultimately, this book didn‚Äôt resonate with me, and I think it‚Äôs a case of the genre not aligning with my personal preferences.

  The story is set in a Russian revolution-inspired world, which in some ways reminded me of *Shadow and Bone*. However, it lacked the well-thought-out fantasy elements that made *Shadow and Bone* compelling.

  I listened to this book as an audio ARC from NetGalley, and I cannot fault the narrator at all‚Äîshe did an amazing job.

  The book struggles to decide what it wants to be. Is it a tense fantasy with life-or-death situations, or a romantasy with just enough deus ex machina to ensure the characters always survive? This inconsistency made it hard to fully engage with the story.

- **Character Development and Motivations:**  
  The main villain felt cartoonish, and her motivations weren‚Äôt very clear. The main characters, regardless of whose POV we were in, oscillated between moments of violent rebellion and thinking about how the other person would be in bed. This lack of focus left me confused at times.

  I feel like this is another case of New Adult Romantasy just not being for me.

review: The first 30 to 40% of the book felt like a slog, and I nearly gave up on it. The story took too long to gain momentum, although it eventually picked up. While the concept was promising, it felt underdeveloped, and many plot elements came across as generic, reminiscent of other books I've read. Although familiarity can be comforting, in this case, it detracted from the overall experience.

The romantic relationships in the story were inconsistent, often feeling immature and more appropriate for young adult or new adult audiences. Although the author tried to elevate the narrative to an adult level with elements of lust and explicit language, this effort ultimately missed the mark. While some banter between Sera and Vitaly was entertaining, the overall execution of the romance left much to be desired.
The world-building and scene-setting were awkward and cumbersome, with overly complex writing that hindered initial engagement with the story.
conclusion: Overall, the book didn‚Äôt resonate with me. Despite a promising concept and some amusing moments, the pacing, world-building, and romantic relationships left much to be desired. The plot lacked originality and felt underdeveloped, making it a somewhat disappointing read.

review: The story centers on foster sisters Sera and Galina, who were subjected to experiments by their foster mother, who implanted them with gods. After their mother was executed for her involvement with the Rebellion, the Faithless, the sisters set out for revenge against the Empress. The narrative is rich with cunning schemes, a fight for justice, morally ambiguous characters, power-hungry nobles, and a strong bond between the sisters. While the second half of the book captivated me, the first half dragged and left important details insufficiently explained.

Sera and Galina drive a gripping tale of revenge, while Vitaly, the devoted assassin, emerges as a standout character and a personal favorite. Vasilisa, the enigmatic princess, captivates with her remarkable character growth as she discovers her true self. Other key figures, including Katya and Princess Vasilisa, contribute significantly to the narrative. The book features enjoyable romances, including a second-chance love story and sapphic relationships, adding depth to the plot.
Although marketed as adult fiction, the book reads more like young adult with a touch of steam.
conclusion: This novel offers a mix of revenge, morally complex characters, and intricate relationships, with a strong focus on sisterly bonds and political intrigue. While the first half was slow and lacked clarity, the second half was engaging and rewarding. The romances, particularly Vitaly‚Äôs devotion and Vasilisa‚Äôs growth, were highlights. Overall, it‚Äôs a compelling read for fans of morally grey characters and devious plots, though it leans more toward YA than adult fiction.

review: This fast-paced novel features shorter chapters and a lighter approach to worldbuilding. It alternates between five main POV characters, offering insight into their actions and romantic entanglements. Set against the backdrop of the Russian Revolution, this multi-POV romantasy follows sisters Galina and Sera, who are bound to powerful dragon-gods known as zmei and raised to dismantle an empire by any means necessary. Galina infiltrates the palace as a handmaiden and encounters Princess Vasilisa, while Sera rekindles her romance with Vitaly, a fellow revolutionary.

The romantic dynamics between Sera and Vitaly are captivating, as Vitaly is determined to win back Sera, while she remains focused on their mission and Galina's safety. In contrast, Galina and Vasilisa's relationship unfolds as an enemies-to-lovers story, providing a fresh perspective alongside Sera and Vitaly's second-chance romance. The chemistry between Galina and Vasilisa is instant, intensified by the bond between their zmei. This novel is highly recommended for fans of Anastasia retellings and those looking for a fantasy with a strong romantic emphasis.
conclusion: *To Cage a God* by Elizabeth May is a fast-paced romantasy with engaging romantic dynamics and a plot inspired by the Russian Revolution. The alternating POVs and shorter chapters make it an accessible and enjoyable read, particularly for fans of romance-driven fantasy.

  - Galina and Vasilisa‚Äôs romance follows an enemies-to-lovers trope, contrasting with Sera and Vitaly‚Äôs second-chance romance.  
  - The attraction between Galina and Vasilisa is immediate, heightened by the connection between their zmei.  

- **Pacing and Structure:**

review: The story grabs your attention right from the first page, maintaining a strong momentum that keeps it engaging and exciting throughout.

review: The plot was engaging and held my interest, but the writing occasionally felt choppy, disrupting the story's flow. This inconsistency detracted from my overall enjoyment and made it difficult to fully immerse myself in the narrative.

I appreciated the dual perspectives of the sisters, Galina and Sera, which created an engaging dynamic. However, the introduction of additional viewpoints later in the book felt unnecessary and diminished my connection to the story. I found myself less invested in these extra perspectives compared to the sisters'. The sapphic romance was a standout element, adding depth and emotional resonance to the narrative. It was both steamy and seamlessly woven into the plot, which I truly enjoyed.

The book delves into profound themes such as the loss of a loved one, alcoholism, chronic illness, fire, emotional abuse, and physical violence. While these elements enrich the narrative, they may be triggering for some readers.

The book's premise is captivating, set in a Russian-inspired fantasy world filled with god possession and political intrigue. The initial comparison to a beloved fantasy trilogy piqued my interest, especially with the compelling story of two sisters, Galina and Sera, who are possessed by dangerous gods while striving to prevent a looming war. This concept holds great potential.
conclusion: While *To Cage a God* has a strong premise, engaging sisterly dynamic, and a well-executed sapphic romance, the choppy writing and unnecessary additional perspectives hindered my overall enjoyment. Fans of Russian-inspired fantasy, political intrigue, and steamy romance may still find this book worth reading, but the execution fell short of its potential for me.

conclusion: Overall, the novel was okay but had significant shortcomings in character development and world-building. While the romances were a highlight, the lack of emotional depth and context made it hard to fully engage with the story or feel invested in the characters' fates.

review: The story is captivating and kept me engaged from beginning to end. However, the ending felt somewhat underwhelming, even as it left me eager to see where the narrative will lead next. It follows Galina and Sera on their quest for revenge against the Empress, who destroyed Galina's village and killed Sera's mother. The nobles and guards wield god-like powers through runes carved into their bones, which allow them to trap dragons from another realm and harness their abilities. Both Galina and Sera were unwilling test subjects of Sera's mother, who discovered how to bind these gods to human bones. Sera has a moderately powerful dragon that harbors a deep resentment towards her, while Galina commands a formidable dragon capable of wielding Godfire for both destruction and healing, as well as extracting dragons from their hosts to return them to their realm.

The story is narrated from multiple perspectives, featuring well-developed characters. The humorous banter enriches the interactions, making even the side characters feel vibrant and endearing. The dual love stories are both steamy and organic, adding depth to the narrative.

conclusion: While the novel has an intriguing premise and a unique setting, it falls short in character depth and world-building. The romance and chronic illness representation are notable, but the story overall feels bland and lacks the moral complexity it initially promises.

review: Both sisters navigate the challenges of wielding immense power against a formidable enemy. Their differing approaches reveal their personal struggles and growth as they confront the moral complexities of their roles in the rebellion.

The narrative is both compelling and thought-provoking, immersing readers in a richly detailed world and its complex characters. The nuanced exploration of themes adds depth, making it a truly memorable read.

This novel intricately explores the theme of rebellion against a tyrannical regime through the lives of sisters Galina and Sera, raised as living weapons imbued with the power of caged gods. Their mission is to overthrow the oppressive Alurea family, who wield devastating god-like power. The narrative follows their divergent paths: Galina infiltrates the opulent palace, entangled in courtly intrigue and a forbidden romance with a princess, while Sera aligns herself with a brutal rebellion movement.
conclusion: To Cage a God is a gripping and thought-provoking novel that masterfully explores the complexities of rebellion, power, and morality. Through the contrasting journeys of Galina and Sera, the story challenges readers to reflect on the true costs of freedom and the sacrifices required to achieve it.

review: The novel maintains a gripping pace filled with high stakes and constant danger. The dual narratives of sisters Galina and Sera‚Äîone infiltrating the palace and the other joining the rebellion‚Äîcreate a palpable sense of urgency and suspense. Both sisters bear gods grafted into their bones, granting them forbidden powers. Raised as living weapons, they are determined to overthrow an empire ruled by a royal family possessed by destructive deities. With their mother gone and their country on the brink of war, Galina and Sera must lead a rebellion to end the cruel reign of the alurea, who conquer through fire and blood.

Galina and Sera are intricately developed characters shaped by their harsh upbringing and the divine forces within them. Galina grapples with internal conflict as she infiltrates the palace and bonds with an isolated princess, whose keen intelligence poses a risk of revealing her true identity. Meanwhile, Sera's reunion with her estranged lover, now a violent rebel leader, adds further complexity to her character.

The novel presents a richly detailed world where gods are intertwined with humans, set against a backdrop of impending war. The ruthless ruling alurea oppress the common folk, who endure great suffering under their reign. Through its narrative, the story delves into themes of power, deception, and the heavy toll of rebellion.

The story explores themes of duty versus desire, the destructive nature of power, and the moral complexities of rebellion. Galina‚Äôs internal conflict‚Äîbalancing her mission with her burgeoning feelings for the princess‚Äîunderscores the tension between personal desires and greater responsibilities.
conclusion: This is a compelling and intricately crafted novel that combines rich world-building, complex characters, and high-stakes conflict. The story explores the moral ambiguities of power and rebellion, keeping readers engaged with its fast-paced narrative and emotional depth.

  The gods and the politics surrounding them, including the empire, the other queens, and the rebel faction, were not well explained. None of the political dynamics were adequately fleshed out.  

- **Character Relationships:**  
  The relationship between Vitaly and Sera felt like it should have had more depth and impact but fell flat. Galina and Vasilia‚Äôs relationship was more tolerable but felt like insta-love.  

- **Characterization of the Gods:**  
  The gods‚Äô personalities were underdeveloped, with their roles reduced to being either grumpy or pleased with their hosts. The potential for a more dynamic and engaging portrayal of the gods was wasted.  

- **Aesthetic Appeal:**  
  Despite its flaws, I‚Äôll be keeping my copy because it‚Äôs one of the prettiest book box books I‚Äôve seen.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the novel has strong writing and an appealing atmosphere, it suffers from a lack of plot coherence, underdeveloped world-building, and shallow character relationships. The potential for a richer exploration of the gods and politics was missed, leaving me disappointed despite the book‚Äôs aesthetic charm.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No explicit rating scores mentioned in the review.)

*To Cage A God* masterfully intertwines high fantasy with dark romantic elements, creating a captivating narrative that features deities and political intrigue. The plot centers on characters gearing up for a rebellion against their oppressors, infusing the story with tension and suspense.
conclusion: *To Cage A God* is a standout novel that successfully merges high fantasy and dark romantasy, offering well-developed characters, a richly built world, and a fresh take on familiar tropes. review: While nearly all the characters had their own chapters, I found myself only invested in Vitalik's story. The majority of the other characters and their narratives left me indifferent. Additionally, the inclusion of lesbian characters seemed more like a marketing strategy to attract diverse audiences, a trend that feels increasingly prevalent in contemporary literature.
The Russia-inspired setting and names failed to resonate with me, and the overall world-building felt underdeveloped.
The book took me over a month to finish, and I found it so dull that I nearly put it down several times.

This story felt overly geared towards a young adult audience, though it may resonate better with that demographic. Additionally, labeling it as a "romantasy" is misleading, as the romance is confined to just a few chapters, which doesn't warrant that genre classification.
conclusion: While the book might appeal to its intended YA audience, it failed to engage me due to its slow pacing, lack of compelling characters, and underdeveloped world-building. The misleading genre classification and the inclusion of certain themes felt more like a marketing strategy than an integral part of the story.

conclusion: Overall, I found the story engaging and well-crafted, particularly the setting, Galina's character arc, and Katya's involvement in the rebellion. While the multiple POVs were a bit overwhelming, the strong ending and compelling characters made it a worthwhile read.

review: The story's slow start and loose plot hindered its overall engagement.

My favorite aspect of the story was undoubtedly the characters. Galina and Sera are both strong, yet they each embody strength in unique ways, making them compelling figures. Their intriguing and poignant backstories left me wishing for a prequel. I also appreciated the additional POVs introduced later in the story, which is noteworthy since I typically prefer 1-2 perspectives. The two romances, though they emerged in the second half of the book, added depth to the narrative.
The occasional vague imagery diminished the overall experience.
I was captivated by the wintery, brutal, Russian-inspired world, which created an immersive and unique atmosphere for the story.
conclusion: Overall, I really enjoyed *To Cage a God* for its strong characters, unique world-building, and engaging romances. However, the slow pacing, loose plot, and occasional vagueness in imagery prevented it from being a 5-star read for me.

  - Their backstories are so interesting and sad that it made me want to read a prequel.  
  - I even enjoyed the POVs that came later in the story, which is saying something from me, as I'm usually a 1-2 POV kind of person.  

- **Romance:**  
  - I enjoyed the two different romances, though they didn‚Äôt come into play until the second half of the book.  

- **Pacing and Plot:**  
  - The slow pace in the beginning and the loose plot kept the story from being as engaging as it could have been.  

- **Imagery and Writing Style:**  
  - The sometimes vague imagery detracted from the overall experience.  

**Conclusion:**  
Overall, I really enjoyed *To Cage a God* for its strong characters, unique world-building, and engaging romances. However, the slow pacing, loose plot, and occasional vagueness in imagery prevented it from being a 5-star read for me.

review: While the premise held promise, the execution ultimately fell short and became confusing. The storytelling lacked coherence, which hindered my ability to remain engaged.
The novel featured numerous captivating elements, such as Imperial Russia, gods trapped in human forms, dragon-like deities, and intricate political intrigue.
I struggled to get through the pages and dreaded picking up my Kindle, ultimately stopping at the 20% mark.
I eagerly anticipated this book due to my love for Slavic literature, which I find rich in history and folklore‚Äîelements I deeply enjoy.
conclusion: While the novel had an intriguing premise with elements I typically enjoy, the confusing execution and lack of engagement made it impossible for me to continue reading. It appears to be a polarizing book, with some readers loving it and others, like me, struggling to connect with it.

- **Author‚Äôs Success:**  
  Despite my personal experience, I wish the author all the success with this book.

**Conclusion:**  
While the novel had an intriguing premise with elements I typically enjoy, the confusing execution and lack of engagement made it impossible for me to continue reading. It appears to be a polarizing book, with some readers loving it and others, like me, struggling to connect with it.

- **Tension and Conflict:**  
  There was very little tension in the story. Whenever a pressing event occurred, one of the two couples (four of the five POVs) would have a corny fade-to-black sex scene, and the problem would be postponed to a future worry. This undermined any sense of urgency or stakes.  

- **World-Building and Language:**  
  The author introduced a lot of made-up language, which could have worked if used sparingly or if the meanings were easily inferred. Instead, there was a three-page language key to help readers understand basic terms like "coat" or various botanical names, which felt excessive and disruptive to the flow of the story.  

**Conclusion:**  
Overall, this book was a struggle to finish due to underdeveloped characters, a poorly structured plot, cringe-worthy dialogue, a lack of tension, and excessive use of made-up language. The story failed to engage or convince me, leaving me disappointed.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

review: The plot was captivating, drawing inspiration from *Six of Crows* and the Grishaverse. Set against a backdrop reminiscent of the Russian Revolution, it features revolutionary gangs infiltrating the imperial castle to challenge the elite, known as the god-bonded. The story delivered intense, edge-of-your-seat moments that kept me deeply invested in the characters and eager to see how the plot would unfold.

The relationships, both romantic and platonic, were beautifully developed throughout the book. I found myself genuinely invested in them and pleasantly surprised by several unexpected twists, particularly as the narrative expanded to include more characters.

The writing posed a significant challenge for me. Each character had several names‚Äîfull names, nicknames, and pet names‚Äîwhich quickly became overwhelming. The use of a Russian-esque language for the gods, magic systems, phrases, and towns further contributed to the confusion. I often found myself wishing for a glossary, which I did eventually locate at the back of the book, and I even pondered whether footnotes might have been beneficial.
Despite some writing challenges, I found the book worthwhile. I'm invested in the character development and will likely read the second book to see where the story leads.
conclusion: While the book had some complexities in its writing style, the engaging character relationships, intriguing plot, and compelling themes made it a worthwhile read. I‚Äôm eager to continue the series to see how the characters and story evolve.

review: This novel, told from multiple perspectives, can be repetitive and occasionally slow-paced. However, the overall storyline is engaging. review: The plot lacked depth and did not fully explore its potential. Key events, like Sera and Galina's effortless infiltration of the palace following the king's death, felt unrealistic and rushed. Additionally, the resolution, in which the protagonists triumph, came across as predictable and unsatisfying.

The characters in the story are unremarkable and lack depth, making it difficult to invest in their actions or fates. Sera and Galina's motivations come across as sudden and unconvincing, particularly Sera's abrupt decision to "fix the world" after years of evasion. Galina lacks agency, merely following Sera without much thought. Vitaly, the morally ambiguous assassin, is a clich√©d trope, especially given his indifference to innocent lives. The romance between Sera and Vitaly feels forced and lacks emotional resonance; their transition from lovers to enemies and back again is clich√©d, and the reveal of their marriage, intended as a pivotal moment, falls flat. Their frequent references to each other as "husband" and "wife" feel excessive and contradict Sera's claim of hating Vitaly. Similarly, the romance between Galina and Vasya is forgettable and uninspired.

The novel was so poorly executed that it became oddly captivating, igniting a morbid curiosity that kept me reading despite my desire to put it down. I found myself compelled to witness the unfolding train wreck, which, in its own way, was strangely entertaining.
conclusion: While the novel had a strange, almost entertaining quality in its flaws, it ultimately fell short in character development, romance, and plot execution. The lack of depth and unconvincing motivations made it hard to fully engage with the story, leaving me questioning why I finished it.

review: The story follows Galina and Sera, two sisters created through their mother's experiments to contain gods within their bodies. Their mission is to overthrow the empire and seek justice for its transgressions. Told from multiple perspectives, the narrative offers a deep dive into the characters' motivations and the political intrigue surrounding their rebellion. With high stakes and a compelling plot, the story leans more towards epic fantasy than romantasy.

While romance elements are present, they take a backseat until the second half of the book, giving the novel an epic fantasy feel reminiscent of *Godkiller* by Hannah Kaner, rather than a traditional romantasy.
This novel presents a darker tone than typical romantasy reads, emphasizing power dynamics, retribution, and the harsh consequences of its magic system.

The author crafts a brutal and intricately designed world, featuring a unique magic system in which gods are imprisoned within infants specifically prepared to receive them in the womb. This arrangement bestows god-like powers upon the ruling class, deepening the divide between them and the rest of society. The Russian influence in the world-building, evident in names and languages, adds depth and evokes comparisons to *Shadow and Bone*.
conclusion: This novel offers a richly crafted world, a unique and dangerous magic system, and a gripping plot centered around political intrigue and retribution. While it includes romance, it leans more toward epic fantasy, making it a great choice for readers seeking a darker, high-stakes story.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**
- **World-Building:**  
  The world created by May is brutal and intricately designed, with a unique magic system where gods are caged within the bodies of infants who have been primed to receive them in the womb. This system grants the ruling class god-like powers, elevating their status and creating a stark divide between them and the rest of society. The Russian influence in the world design, including names and languages, adds depth and reminds me of *Shadow and Bone*.  

- **Plot and Themes:**  
  The story revolves around Galina and Sera, who are products of experiments by their mother. They are altered to cage gods within their bodies, with the goal of overthrowing the empire and seeking retribution for its crimes. The narrative is told through multiple points of view, providing insights into the characters working to overthrow the realm. The political aspects are compelling, and the stakes are high, making the story feel more aligned with epic fantasy than romantasy.  

- **Romance:**  
  Romance elements are present but take a backseat until the second half of the book. This makes the novel feel more like an epic fantasy, such as *Godkiller* by Hannah Kaner, rather than a traditional romantasy.  

- **Tone and Style:**  
  The novel has a darker tone compared to standard romantasy reads, with a focus on power dynamics, retribution, and the brutal consequences of the magic system.  

**Conclusion:**  
This novel offers a richly crafted world, a unique and dangerous magic system, and a gripping plot centered around political intrigue and retribution. While it includes romance, it leans more toward epic fantasy, making it a great choice for readers seeking a darker, high-stakes story.

review: This dark fantasy weaves a tale of politics, revenge, and vengeful gods, with a powerful focus on female rage. The intricate plot of vengeance is beautifully complemented by a romance that endears the characters Sera and Galina to the reader. While the elements of science and academia are minimal, they create a unique link to the magic system, exemplified by the synthesis of plants to replicate ancient processes.

This multi-POV novel features chapters from Sera, Galina, Vasilisa, Katya, and Vitaly, enriching the narrative by offering diverse perspectives. Katya emerges as a standout character, admired for her bravery and resilience as the Empress‚Äôs handmaiden, working alongside Sera and Galina to challenge the empire. In contrast, Vitaly falls flat; his character feels overly dependent on Sera, rendering his role in the plot somewhat unnecessary. The romance between Sera and Galina is compelling and adds significant depth to the story. While Vitaly‚Äôs expressions of love and anger toward Sera are sweet and relatable, his character lacks substance without her.
The story is well-crafted, featuring clear character motivations and development that make their actions easy to understand.
conclusion: *To Cage a God* is a captivating dark fantasy with a strong focus on revenge, politics, and female rage. The multi-POV structure and intricate magic system add depth to the story, though some characters, like Vitaly, feel underdeveloped. The romance between Sera and Galina is a highlight, making this a highly enjoyable read.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Plot and Themes:**  
  The story is a dark fantasy filled with politics, revenge, and spiteful gods, with a strong emphasis on female rage. It‚Äôs an intricate tale of revenge intertwined with a romance plot that makes you fall in love with the characters Sera and Galina. The inclusion of science and academia, though minimal, adds a unique connection to the magic system, such as replicating an age-old process by synthesizing plants.  

- **Character Development and POVs:**  
  The novel is multi-POV, with chapters from Sera, Galina, Vasilisa, Katya, and Vitaly. The range of perspectives enriches the story, allowing readers to experience it through different lenses. Katya stands out as a favorite due to her bravery and resilience as the Empress‚Äôs handmaiden working to overthrow the empire alongside Sera and Galina. On the other hand, Vitaly is the least favorite character, as he feels flat and overly dependent on Sera, making his presence seem unnecessary to the overall plot.  

- **Romance and Relationships:**  
  The romance between Sera and Galina is compelling and adds depth to the story. Vitaly‚Äôs expressions of love and anger toward Sera are sweet and understandable, but his character lacks depth without her.  

- **Writing Style:**  
  The story is well-written, with clear motivations and development for the characters, making it easy to understand why they act the way they do.  

**Conclusion:**  
*To Cage a God* is a captivating dark fantasy with a strong focus on revenge, politics, and female rage. The multi-POV structure and intricate magic system add depth to the story, though some characters, like Vitaly, feel underdeveloped. The romance between Sera and Galina is a highlight, making this a highly enjoyable read.  

**Rating Scores:**  
- Overall Rating: 4.5 stars  
- Spice Rating: 1.5/5

Galina‚Äôs evolution is particularly satisfying; she overcomes her traumas, asserts herself, and emerges as a strong heroine who achieves the impossible.

While I initially found it confusing to navigate the various villages, towns, and districts, I soon acclimated. The concept of alureas‚Äîhumans with dragon-gods trapped in their bones‚Äîis both original and intriguing. Their ruthless actions, like incinerating entire villages without leaving survivors, add significant depth to the world.
conclusion: To Cage A God is a captivating fantasy novel with a richly imagined world, compelling characters, and a narrative that keeps you engaged. review: This thrilling tale of love, sedition, and revolution unfolds in a Russian-inspired fantasy world. Set against the backdrop of significant historical events, it follows Galina and her foster sister Sera as they hide after their adoptive mother Irina's failed revolution. When the emperor is assassinated, Sera persuades Galina to rejoin the struggle and infiltrate the palace to overthrow the empress without igniting a civil war. The plot is captivating, featuring a satisfying arc that culminates in a violent confrontation while leaving space for future developments.

The characters are well-developed, each with distinct goals, personalities, and secrets. Central to the story is the relationship between Galina and Sera, shaped by their shared trauma and revolutionary past. The diverse cast introduces a range of romantic tropes, including second-chance romance, enemies-to-lovers, forbidden love, and princess-and-commoner dynamics. The palpable romantic tension features moments sure to captivate fantasy romance fans.

The story unfolds through multiple perspectives, introducing new characters about a third of the way in. Each character is actively involved in the plot, and the author skillfully distinguishes their voices. The pacing is well-balanced, maintaining my engagement throughout.

The magic system is both unique and captivating. Dragon gods inhabit human hosts, granting them extraordinary powers. These dragons are physically confined within their hosts, navigating through internal organs. This intriguing concept not only enhances the world-building but also adds a thrilling layer to the narrative.

This book delves into themes of revolution, power, and morally complex characters. It features beloved tropes like magical uprisings, diverse casts, and ambiguous heroes and heroines. The Russian-inspired setting enriches the narrative with a captivating cultural backdrop.
conclusion: *To Cage A God* is a captivating novel that combines magical revolution, complex characters, and a unique magic system within a richly imagined Russian-inspired fantasy world. With its fiery romantic tension, diverse cast, and morally gray protagonists, it‚Äôs a must-read for fans of fantasy romance and revolutionary tales. The story‚Äôs satisfying arc and unresolved threads set the stage for an exciting continuation.

review: The story unfolds at a brisk pace, with short chapters that maintain an engaging rhythm. However, the ending felt rushed, leaving me wanting more after the promising build-up.

review: The first 50 pages set the scene at a slow pace, but the story quickly becomes engaging and compelling. While the use of five different POVs initially feels overwhelming, it ultimately enhances the pacing and keeps the narrative flowing smoothly.

The story features both straight and sapphic romantic relationships, but the sapphic love story stands out as more engaging and compelling. It‚Äôs refreshing to see a queer relationship take center stage.

Set in Imperial Russia with a fantasy twist, this book offers a compelling perspective from revolutionaries. It delves into themes of politics, power dynamics, and resistance against the wealthy elite. The introduction of god powers creates a distinct divide between the powerful and the impoverished, with gods caged within select individuals. This intriguing concept adds depth and freshness to the familiar overarching narrative.
conclusion: This book combines political intrigue, revolutionary themes, and unique fantasy elements to create a compelling story. Despite a slow start, the multiple POVs and engaging sapphic romance kept me hooked. The world-building is imaginative, and the potential for more stories in this universe leaves me eager for more.
